repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan Power Sector
            Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rajasthan Power Sector
            Restructuring Project for India were as follows: outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include: risks to project outcome should be
            carefully analyzed and taken into account. In particular,
            attention should be paid to climatic hazards and to subsidy
            regimes in other States and their likely impact on the
            political viability of proposed reforms. Covenanted
            objectives should reflect a realistic judgment of the
            leverage accorded by investment projects on complex policy
            issues, and of factors outside the control of the project.
            More systematic monitoring of experience in other, similar
            projects will have helped to avoid the repetition of
            over-ambitious design apparent in the five State power
            sector restructuring operations in India, even though
            convincing evidence may not have been fully available at the
            preparation stage, the opportunity should have been taken
            during implementation to restructure. Such monitoring will
            facilitate a clearer and more objective assessment of
            progress towards achievement of the project development
            objectives during supervision missions. A careful assessment
            of international trends in power sector private investment
            in developing countries should also be part of the exercise.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan Power Sector
            Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rajasthan Power Sector
            Restructuring Project in India were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Lessons learned were: 1) the expectation of
            the pace at which the reforms can be implemented and the
            outcomes realized should be realistic. Given the
            socio-political constraints the pace of reforms will be
            determined by the willingness and capacity of the
            governments to address key reform issues; 2) subsidized
            power supply to agriculture is a broad public policy issue,
            not just a sectoral issue. The problem of subsidized power
            supply to agriculture and resistance to metering is embedded
            in the political economy of distorted agricultural policies.
            Sustainable improvement in power sector requires this
            complex economic and political problem to be addressed; 3)
            tariff reforms and cost recovery improvement as well as
            efficiency improvement are essential for the financial
            turnaround of the power sector. Tariff subsidy to the
            consumers must be explicitly defined and transparently
            delivered without compromising the utility's finances;
            4) public acceptance of sector changes and consequent
            prospects of sustainability are likely to only come about if
            the changes result in quickly achieved and highly visible
            improvements in service quality; and 5) in future, and in
            general through out the various sectors, while encouragement
            may well be given for ICB package sizes to be large to
            encourage international participation and economies of
            scale, every effort should be made, through market research
            by the borrower, to ensure that lot sizes are so finalized
            as to ensure that eligible bids will be received from the
            most likely source.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan Power Sector
            Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rajasthan Power Sector Restructuring
            Project will support the State power sector reform process,
            and improve sector efficiency and financial recovery, as
            well as power supply, reducing critical bottlenecks in the
            power transmission, and distribution system. The components
            will: 1) reduce Rajasthan State Electricity Board's
            (RSEB) technical, and non-technical losses through an
            immediate elimination of the long lower voltage, or low
            tension lines in rural areas, which heavily overload
            transformers. Schemes will be financed, consisting of low
            tension-less systems, replacing low voltage lines with high
            voltage, and further augment locations of distribution
            transformers, while capacitor installation will further
            improve returns of operating voltages; 2) reinforce
            transmission/distribution systems, by financing equipment,
            materials, and plant, for substations
            expansion/construction; 3) install system electronic
            (static) meters to measure the flow of electricity, a
            prerequisite for successful commercialization; and, 4)
            provide technical assistance in the areas of reform project
            management; institutional development; formation of joint
            venture distribution companies; socioeconomic impact
            assessment; renewable energy development; environmental
            management; and, communications/information, particularly
            supporting the public information campaign through various
            media forms.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan State Power Sector
            Restructuring Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The report is the environmental
            assessment for the Rajasthan State Power Sector
            Restructuring Project, and addresses potential adverse
            effects on the environment as a result of the project.
            Adverse environmental impacts, and mitigating measures
            follow. Transmission lines, and substations will not disturb
            natural habitats, for those will be installed within 100 km
            of any wild life protection area, and, though lines pass
            through agricultural land, cultivation is permitted under
            the towers, and conductors, posing no threat to the
            surroundings. Soil erosion during construction will be
            controlled through the installation of retaining walls, and
            stone pitching, and, vegetation propagation will be ensured
            as needed. However, there is the potential for
            electromagnetic frequency (EMF) radiation, noise
            disturbances, and electric interference along transmission
            lines, therefore minimum transmission line clearance
            distances will address EMF effects, in accordance with the
            Electricity Act. Furthermore, the potential of electrocution
            hazard exist, thus the Rajasthan State Electricity Board
            will restrict public access, by fencing substations in
            accordance with the Electricity Act. The second volume,
            Social Policy and Procedures, address displaced populations
            losing land, who will be compensated as per the Land
            Acquisition Act, through rehabilitation grants to ensure
            replacement values.

docna.cdata!:
Environmental framework and safeguards for
            transmission projects

display_title.display_title:
India - Rajasthan State Power
            Sector Restructuring Project : environmental assessment :
            Environmental framework and safeguards for transmission projects
